newsitem.title: UK: IRA "rumour-mongering" on N.Irish truce - Trimble.
newsitem.headline: IRA "rumour-mongering" on N.Irish truce - Trimble.

text.p: Pro-British leader David Trimble accused the outlawed Irish Republican Army on Monday of rumour-mongering about a truce in the Northern Irish conflict.
The Ulster Unionist Party (UUP) leader also attacked Britain for fuelling fears that it might ease terms to give guerrillas a voice in peace talks.
"The IRA (Irish Republican Army) have set in process a whole series of rumours about ceasefires," Trimble said after weekend reports that a guerrilla truce had been operating for the past six weeks.
"I don't think there's much substance to this because I don't think they (the IRA) can meet the requirements (specified by Britain and Ireland)," he told BBC radio.

Britain and Sinn Fein, the IRA's political wing, have both repudiated a Dublin Sunday newspaper report of an unofficial truce which added to a flurry of speculation over the strategy of IRA hawks who ended a truce in February, plunging peace efforts into chaos.
Some 200 members of Sinn Fein, which is currently excluded from multi-party talks because of IRA violence, are to hold a special conference in the Irish Republic on Saturday.
A party spokesman in Dublin said it was being held "for the purposes of discussing the processes of conflict resolution" and would take place in private at an undisclosed location.

The conference is to be addressed by Martin McGuinness, the party's chief strategist who said last week that the IRA would not call a truce unless Britain agreed to give Sinn Fein a place in unconditional peace talks.

Trimble, who wants the IRA to disarm before Sinn Fein is admitted to the talks, said the IRA aimed to persuade London to abandon its demands for a truce and a firm commitment to peace as the price of Sinn Fein's entry into the negotiations.

The UUP leader, whose party has a nine-vote bloc in the British parliament that is increasingly crucial to the Conservative government's survival, chided British Northern Ireland Secretary Sir Patrick Mayhew for making a public reply to McGuinness's demands on the terms of entry to talks.
"He clearly appears to be trying to semaphore something to the IRA," Trimble said.
"I think it's bound to give rise to a certain amount of unease among people when...they wonder is there any fire behind this smoke."
Earlier, Gary McMichael, leader of the political arm of the UDA, a banned pro-British extremist group, said secret British deals with the IRA could wreck peace efforts.
McMichael said he believed Sinn Fein was seeking concessions as a reward for a new IRA ceasefire.

The IRA's last attack in its guerrilla war against British rule of Northern Ireland was on October 7, when it bombed Britain's army headquarters in Northern Ireland, killing a soldier and injuring 30 people.
